maml:description.maml:para: Associates a target to a custom collection target.

The Add-AzureSqlJobChildTarget cmdlet associates a target to a custom collection target. Jobs that are run targeting custom collections are expanded to target all targets associated within the custom collection at the time this cmdlet is run.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the custom collection target to contain the association of the provided database.
Specifies the ID of the target to add into the provided custom collection.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the custom collection target to contain the association of the provided database.
Specifies the database name of the database target to add as a child target to the specified custom collection.
Specifies the server name of the database target to add as a child target to the specified custom collection.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the custom collection target to contain the association of the provided database.
Specifies the database name of the database target to add as a child target to the specified custom collection.
Specifies the server name of the database target to add as a child target to the specified custom collection.
Specifies the ID of the target to add into the provided custom collection.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Add a database target to a custom collection as a child target
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureSqlDatabaseJobChildTarget -CustomCollectionName "MyCustomCollection" -ServerName "MyServer.database.contoso.net" -DatabaseName "MyDatabase"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a database target to a custom collection as a child target. You must first create the database target using the New-AzureSqlDatabaseJobTarget cmdlet. Database targets can be child targets of multiple custom collections.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Add a custom collection to another custom collection
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureSqlDatabaseJobChildTarget -CustomCollectionName "MyCustomCollection" -TargetId (Get-AzureSqlDatabaseJobTarget -CustomCollectionName "MyOtherCustomCollection").TargetId

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a custom collection to another custom collection.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets one or multiple content definitions that are run or applied across entities within a job target.
The Get-AzureSqlJobContentDefinition cmdlet gets one or multiple content definitions that are run or applied across entities within a job target.
The definition includes either the T-SQL script for T-SQL content or the DACPAC URI for DACPAC content.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Indicates that all versions of the content's definitions are returned.
Specifies the name of the content.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the content.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the content.
Specifies the particular version of content definition to return.
Indicates that all versions of the content's definitions are returned.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the content.
Specifies the particular version of content definition to return.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get all versioned content definitions for a given content name
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobContentDefinition -ContentName "CreateMyTestTable" CommandText ContentName VersionNumber Comment ----------- ----------- ------------- ------- IF NOT EXISTS (SELECT name... CreateMyTestTable 1

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all versioned content definitions for a given content name.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get a specific versioned content definition for a given content name
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobContentDefinition -ContentName "CreateMyTestTable" -Version 1 CommandText ContentName VersionNumber Comment ----------- ----------- ------------- ------- IF NOT EXISTS (SELECT name... CreateMyTestTable 1

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets a specific versioned content definition for a given content name.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets content containers to run or apply across entities in a target.
The Get-AzureSqlJobContent cmdlet gets one or multiple content containers that can be run or applied across entities within a job target.
Content contains one or multiple versioned definitions. You can get versioned definitions by using the Get-AzureSqlJobContentDefinition cmdlet.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies an array that contains the content.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies an array that contains the content.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get all content defined in the system
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobContent ContentName ContentType ----------- ----------- MyDacpac Dacpac MyScript Script CreateMyTestTable Script

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all content defined within the system.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get content for a specified name
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobContent -ContentName "MyScript" ContentName ContentType ----------- ----------- MyScript Script

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets content for the specified name.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets one or multiple database credentials to use when connecting to databases for execution of jobs.

The Get-AzureSqlJobCredential cmdlet gets one or multiple database credentials to use when connecting to databases for execution of jobs. Passwords are encrypted prior to transmission within creation and are not returned through get requests.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the credential.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the credential.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get the credential stored within the system using the provided name
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobCredential -CredentialName MyCredential CredentialName UserName -------------- -------- MyCredential MyUsername

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the credential stored within the system using the provided name.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get all credentials stored within the system
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobCredential CredentialName UserName -------------- -------- MyCredential MyUsername MyCredential2 MyUsername2

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get all credentials stored within the system.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets one or multiple job execution policies.
The Get-AzureSqlJobExecutionPolicy cmdlet gets one or multiple job execution policies.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the execution policy to retrieve.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the execution policy to retrieve.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get an execution policy
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicyName myCustomExecutionPolicyName ExecutionPolicyName : myCustomExecutionPolicyName JobExecutionTimeout : 01:00:00 InitialRetryInterval : 00:00:01 RetryIntervalBackoffCoefficient : 1 MaximumRetryInterval : 00:00:30 MaximumAttempts : 100

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets an execution policy.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets one or multiple job execution containers.
The Get-AzureSqlJobExecution cmdlet gets one or multiple job execution containers. Each job execution container contains task executions performed to fulfill execution of a job.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the content name to use for filtering across all job executions.
Indicates whether children job runs are included within the job output.
Indicates whether job runs are included within the job output.
Specifies the job name to use for filtering across all job executions.

Specifies that this cmdlet filters the job executions by User, Cleanup, Heartbeat or TelemetryCollection job types. All jobs created through New-AzureSqlJob are of type User. System jobs are of type Cleanup, Heartbeat or TelemetryCollection.
Specifies the parent job execution ID to use for filtering across all job executions.
Specifies the schedule name to use for filtering across all job executions.
Specifies the target ID to use for filtering across all job executions.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Indicates whether children job runs are included within the job output.
Specifies the ID of the job execution to obtain.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the content name to use for filtering across all job executions.
Indicates whether children job runs are included within the job output.
Indicates whether job runs are included within the job output.
Specifies the ID of the job execution to obtain.
Specifies the job name to use for filtering across all job executions.

Specifies that this cmdlet filters the job executions by User, Cleanup, Heartbeat or TelemetryCollection job types. All jobs created through New-AzureSqlJob are of type User. System jobs are of type Cleanup, Heartbeat or TelemetryCollection.
Specifies the parent job execution ID to use for filtering across all job executions.
Specifies the schedule name to use for filtering across all job executions.
Specifies the target ID to use for filtering across all job executions.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get all active parent job executions across the system
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobExecution JobExecutionId : e1b85439-14af-453e-a462-04cd17e1d3ec ParentJobExecutionId : Lifecycle : WaitingToRetry CreatedTime : 7/10/2015 1:59:06 PM -07:00 StartTime : 7/10/2015 1:59:08 PM -07:00 EndTime : JobName : MyJob ContentName : MyScript ContentVersionNumber : 1 TargetDescription : {"CustomCollectionName":"myCustomCollection"} TargetId : b525727e-6ed0-44cc-94da-63c543e383d7 CredentialName : MyCredential ExecutionPolicyName : Default execution policy ResultSetDestination :

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all active parent job executions across the system.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get the specified job execution by ID
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobExecution -JobExecutionId e1b85439-14af-453e-a462-04cd17e1d3ec JobExecutionId : e1b85439-14af-453e-a462-04cd17e1d3ec ParentJobExecutionId : Lifecycle : WaitingToRetry CreatedTime : 7/10/2015 1:59:06 PM -07:00 StartTime : 7/10/2015 1:59:08 PM -07:00 EndTime : JobName : MyJob ContentName : MyScript ContentVersionNumber : 1 TargetDescription : {"CustomCollectionName":"myCustomCollection"} TargetId : b525727e-6ed0-44cc-94da-63c543e383d7 CredentialName : MyCredential ExecutionPolicyName : Default execution policy ResultSetDestination :

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the specified job execution by ID.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Get all active job executions across the specified job name
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobExecution -JobName "MyJob" JobExecutionId : e1b85439-14af-453e-a462-04cd17e1d3ec ParentJobExecutionId : Lifecycle : WaitingToRetry CreatedTime : 7/10/2015 1:59:06 PM -07:00 StartTime : 7/10/2015 1:59:08 PM -07:00 EndTime : JobName : MyJob ContentName : MyScript ContentVersionNumber : 1 TargetDescription : {"CustomCollectionName":"myCustomCollection"} TargetId : b525727e-6ed0-44cc-94da-63c543e383d7 CredentialName : MyCredential ExecutionPolicyName : Default execution policy ResultSetDestination :

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all active job executions across the specified job name.

command:example.maml:title: Example 4: Get all active job executions across the specified job name, including child jobs
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobExecution -JobName "CreateTableJob" -IncludeChildren JobExecutionId : a664a3d1-0dba-4516-ad53-bf26115bfaa0 ParentJobExecutionId : Lifecycle : WaitingForChildJobExecutions CreatedTime : 7/10/2015 3:17:26 PM -07:00 StartTime : 7/10/2015 3:17:27 PM -07:00 EndTime : JobName : CreateTableJob ContentName : CreateMyTestTable ContentVersionNumber : 1 TargetDescription : {"CustomCollectionName":"myCustomCollection"} TargetId : b525727e-6ed0-44cc-94da-63c543e383d7 CredentialName : MyCredential ExecutionPolicyName : Default execution policy ResultSetDestination :
JobExecutionId : c0d1433f-ca50-4cc4-81e2-80bcdf5ad258 ParentJobExecutionId : a664a3d1-0dba-4516-ad53-bf26115bfaa0 Lifecycle : InProgress CreatedTime : 7/10/2015 3:17:31 PM -07:00 StartTime : 7/10/2015 3:17:32 PM -07:00 EndTime : JobName : CreateTableJob ContentName : CreateMyTestTable ContentVersionNumber : 1 TargetDescription : {"ServerName":"myServer.database.windows.net","DatabaseName":"myDatabase"} TargetId : 0f31294a-f42f-414d-a00f-4df43e9bd493 CredentialName : MyCredential ExecutionPolicyName : Default execution policy ResultSetDestination :

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all active job executions across the specified job name, including the child job executions.

command:example.maml:title: Example 5: Get all active parent job executions across the system executing specific content
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobExecution -ContentName MyScript JobExecutionId : e1b85439-14af-453e-a462-04cd17e1d3ec ParentJobExecutionId : Lifecycle : WaitingToRetry CreatedTime : 7/10/2015 1:59:06 PM -07:00 StartTime : 7/10/2015 1:59:08 PM -07:00 EndTime : JobName : MyJob ContentName : MyScript ContentVersionNumber : 1 TargetDescription : {"CustomCollectionName":"myCustomCollection"} TargetId : b525727e-6ed0-44cc-94da-63c543e383d7 CredentialName : MyCredential ExecutionPolicyName : Default execution policy ResultSetDestination :

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all active parent job executions across the system executing the specified content.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets one or multiple job schedules.
The Get-AzureSqlJobSchedule cmdlet gets one or multiple job schedules. A schedule is a time specification for a job run to take place either on a reoccurring interval or at a single time.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the job. When specified, this cmdlet returns schedules bounded to the provided job name through a trigger.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the schedule to retrieve.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the job. When specified, this cmdlet returns schedules bounded to the provided job name through a trigger.
Specifies the name of the schedule to retrieve.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get all job schedules
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobSchedule ScheduleName Interval StartTime EndTime
------------ -------- --------- -------
System schedule: telemetry Days: 1 12/31/1999 8:21:08 PM -08:00 12/31/9999 3:59:59 PM -08:00 System schedule: heartbeat Minutes: 5 1/1/0001 12:00:00 AM -08:00 12/31/9999 3:59:59 PM -08:00 System schedule: cleanup Minutes: 5 1/1/0001 12:00:00 AM -08:00 12/31/9999 3:59:59 PM -08:00 MyOneTimeSchedule OneTime 7/15/2015 7:00:00 AM -07:00 12/31/9999 3:59:59 PM -08:00 MyOneMinuteIntervalSchedule Minutes: 1 7/4/2015 7:00:00 AM -07:00 12/31/9999 3:59:59 PM -08:00 MyOneHourIntervalSchedule Hours: 1 7/4/2015 7:00:00 AM -07:00 12/31/9999 3:59:59 PM -08:00 MyOneDayIntervalSchedule Days: 1 7/4/2015 7:00:00 AM -07:00 12/31/9999 3:59:59 PM -08:00

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all job schedules.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get the job schedule for a specified schedule
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobSchedule -ScheduleName "MyOneTimeSchedule" ScheduleName Interval StartTime EndTime ------------ -------- --------- ------- MyOneTimeSchedule OneTime 7/15/2015 7:00:00 AM -07:00 12/31/9999 3:59:59 PM -08:00

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the schedule for the schedule named MyOneTimeSchedule.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets one or multiple results of a script batch execution within a task execution.

The Get-AzureSqlJobScriptBatchExecution cmdlet gets one or multiple results of a script batch run within a task execution. Each task run for script execution also create one or multiple script batch executions.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the job task execution ID to use for lookup of script batch executions.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the job task execution ID to use for lookup of script batch executions.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get the results of execution from each batch within a script
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobScriptBatchExecution -JobTaskExecutionId fd3be7b5-f860-4068-93b1-4a3b2d7c3ef3 ScriptBatchNumber : 0 Lifecycle : Succeeded StartTime : 7/10/2015 3:32:07 PM -07:00 EndTime : 7/10/2015 3:32:08 PM -07:00 Message :

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the results of the specified job task execution from each batch within a script. The job task execution ID must match a job task of type ScriptExecution.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets one or multiple containers of databases that can be used as a target for job runs.
The Get-AzureSqlJobTarget cmdlet gets one or multiple containers of databases that can be used as a target for job execution.

There are multiple supported types of targets, namely custom collection targets, database targets, and Elastic Scale shard map targets. Each target type can be retrieved through the different parameter sets within this cmdlet.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the target ID.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the parent target ID. If you specify this parameter, this cmdlet returns all child targets of the specified parent target ID.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of a database within a database target to retrieve.
Specifies the name of a database server within a database target to retrieve.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the elastic scale shard map database name.
Specifies the elastic scale shard map server name.
Specifies the elastic scale shard map name.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the custom collection to retrieve.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the parent custom collection name to retrieve targets. This cmdlet gets all child targets of the specified custom…

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the custom collection to retrieve.
Specifies the name of a database within a database target to retrieve.
Specifies the name of the parent custom collection name to retrieve targets. This cmdlet gets all child targets of the specified custom…
Specifies the parent target ID. If you specify this parameter, this cmdlet returns all child targets of the specified parent target ID.
Specifies the name of a database server within a database target to retrieve.
Specifies the elastic scale shard map database name.
Specifies the elastic scale shard map server name.
Specifies the elastic scale shard map name.
Specifies the target ID.

CustomCollection

maml:description.maml:para: Gets one or multiple task run results.
The Get-AzureSqlJobTaskExecution cmdlet gets one or multiple task run results.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the job execution ID.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the job task execution ID.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the job execution ID.
Specifies the job task execution ID.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get all task executions for the specified job execution ID
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobTaskExecution -JobExecutionId 07981e74-5235-48a6-b24e-b5beb16a149a JobTaskExecutionId : ac618be9-9a9c-4308-9652-42c8420aa9a4 JobTaskType : ScriptSplit Lifecycle : Failed CreatedTime : 7/10/2015 2:01:04 PM -07:00 StartTime : 7/10/2015 2:01:04 PM -07:00 EndTime : 7/10/2015 2:01:04 PM -07:00 Message : System.AggregateException: One or more errors occurred. ---> Microsoft.Azure.SqlDatabase.Jobs.Common.UserException: An exception occured while executing command on behalf of the user. See inner exception for details. ---> System.AggregateException: One or more syntax errors occurred. ---> System.InvalidOperationException: 46010: Incorrect syntax near \. (Line 19, Column 16)

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get the specified job execution task

maml:description.maml:para: Gets one or multiple job triggers.

The Get-AzureSqlJobTrigger cmdlet gets one or multiple job triggers. A job trigger is a mapping of job to schedules. In accordance to the schedule definition, job runs are triggered for each job or schedule mapping.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the job name. If you specify this parameter, this cmdlet returns triggers that are bounded to the provided job name.
Specifies the schedule name. If you specify this parameter, this cmdlet returns triggers that are bounded to the provided schedule name.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the job name. If you specify this parameter, this cmdlet returns triggers that are bounded to the provided job name.
Specifies the schedule name. If you specify this parameter, this cmdlet returns triggers that are bounded to the provided schedule name.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get all job triggers using the specified job name
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobTrigger -JobName "MyJob" JobName ScheduleName Enabled ------- ------------ ------- MyJob MyOneMinuteIntervalSchedule True

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all job triggers under the job named MyJob.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get all job triggers using a specified job schedule
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobTrigger -ScheduleName "MyOneMinuteIntervalSchedule" JobName ScheduleName Enabled ------- ------------ ------- MyJob MyOneMinuteIntervalSchedule True

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all job triggers using the schedule named MyOneMinuteIntervalSchedule.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Get all triggers defined in the system
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureSqlJobTrigger JobName ScheduleName Enabled ------- ------------ ------- System Job: telemetry System schedule: telemetry True System Job: heartbeat System schedule: heartbeat True System Job: cleanup System schedule: cleanup True MyJob MyOneMinuteIntervalSchedule True

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all triggers defined in the system.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a connection to an Elastic Database jobs database.
The New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet creates a connection to an Elastic Database jobs database.

Different elastic database jobs use the object that this cmdlet creates within the AzureSqlDatabaseJobConnection optional parameter. Alternatively, you can use the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet to set the job connection within the Azure PowerShell session context and avoid having to pass the connection as a parameter to subsequent elastic database job cmdlet invocations.
Specifies the name of the Azure resource group that contains the Elastic Database Jobs control database. The cmdlet identifies the Elastic Database Jobs control database within the resource group.
Specifies the PSCredential containing the username and password for the elastic database job control database connections.
Indicates that the elastic database jobs control database is looked up within the current subscription by finding the Azure SQL Database within the __ElasticDatabaseJobs resource group.
Specifies the PSCredential containing the username and password for the elastic database job control database connections.
Specifies the database name of the elastic database jobs control database.
Specifies the database server name of the Elastic Database Jobs control database.
Specifies the PSCredential containing the username and password for the elastic database job control database connections.
Indicates that the elastic database jobs control database is looked up within the current subscription by finding the Azure SQL Database within the __ElasticDatabaseJobs resource group.
Specifies the database name of the elastic database jobs control database.
Specifies the name of the Azure resource group that contains the Elastic Database Jobs control database. The cmdlet identifies the Elastic Database Jobs control database within the resource group.
Specifies the database server name of the Elastic Database Jobs control database.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get a connection to the Elastic Database Jobs database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureSqlJobConnection -CurrentAzureSubscription ServerName DatabaseName UserName Password ---------- ------------ -------- -------- edj0acd6992d61445a7b3b4a.d... edj0acd6992d61445a7b3b4a PattiFul System.Security.SecureString

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets a connection to the Elastic Database Jobs database previously installed within the current Azure subscription within the __ElasticDatabaseJobs resource group. This cmdlet prompts you for credentials.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get a connection to an Elastic Database Jobs database that exists on a server
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureSqlJobConnection -ServerName "MyServer" -DatabaseName "MyDatabase" ServerName DatabaseName UserName Password ---------- ------------ -------- -------- myServer myDatabase PattiFul System.Security.SecureString

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets a connection to an Elastic Database Jobs database named myDatabase that exists on server MyServer. This cmdlet prompts you for credentials.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates content that can be run or applied across entities within a job target.
The New-AzureSqlJobContent cmdlet creates content that can be run or applied across entities within a job target. Content can be created in the form of T-SQL scripts or DACPAC URIs.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the command text of a T-SQL script. The script can contain GO statements. When containing GO statements, the system splits the command text into multiple batches.
Specifies the name of the content.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the content.
Specifies the URI for a DACPAC to be used for application. The URI must be accessible by the system.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the command text of a T-SQL script. The script can contain GO statements. When containing GO statements, the system splits the command text into multiple batches.
Specifies the name of the content.
Specifies the URI for a DACPAC to be used for application. The URI must be accessible by the system.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Create a T-SQL script to be used for execution
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureSqlJobContent -ContentName "CreateMyTestTable" -CommandText "IF NOT EXISTS (SELECT name FROM SYS.TABLES WHERE name = 'MyTestTable') BEGIN CREATE TABLE MyTestTable(X INT PRIMARY KEY IDENTITY, Y INT) END" ContentName ContentType ----------- ----------- CreateMyTestTable Script

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a T-SQL script to be used for execution within a job.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Import a T-SQL script from a file to be used for execution
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureSqlJobContent -ContentName "MyScript" -CommandText (Get-Content .\MyScript.sql) ContentName ContentType ----------- ----------- MyScript Script

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command imports a T-SQL script from a file to be used for execution within a job.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Create DACPAC content to be used for execution within a job
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureSqlJobContent -ContentName "MyDacpac" -DacpacUri "http://mystorageaccount.blob.core.windows.net/myContainer/mydacpac.dacpac?sv=2014-02-14&sr=c&sig=7q%2FpZvcD2ivMgiqZ2qwNF6GBI8XLPmAz3%2B4hfbtQf4k%3D&st=2015-06-12T07%3A00%3A00Z&se=2099-06-20T07%3A00%3A00Z&sp=r" ContentName ContentType ----------- ----------- MyDacpac Dacpac

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates DACPAC content to be used for execution within a job. The provided URI should be publically accessible to allow the system to successfully apply the DACPAC across the job target.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates database credentials when connecting to databases to run jobs.

The New-AzureSqlJobCredential cmdlet creates database credentials (username and password) when connecting to databases to run jobs. Passwords are encrypted locally prior to transmission through the use of a public key stored within the Elastic Database Jobs database.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies that the certificate's thumbprint must match the provided thumbprint prior to encryption of the password.
Specifies the PSCredential containing the username and password.
Specifies the name of the credential.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the PSCredential containing the username and password.
Specifies the name of the credential.
Specifies that the certificate's thumbprint must match the provided thumbprint prior to encryption of the password.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Create a new credential using the specified name
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureSqlJobCredential -CredentialName MyCredential CredentialName UserName -------------- -------- MyCredential MyUsername

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a new credential using the provided name. Following cmdlet invocation, you are prompted for the username and password credentials.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates an execution policy which controls job execution timeouts.
The New-AzureSqlJobExecutionPolicy cmdlet creates an execution policy which controls job execution timeouts, retry limits and intervals between job task execution retries.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the time interval to use between job task executions following a job task execution failure.
Specifies the timeout to enforce for overall job execution time.
Specifies the total number of job task execution retry attempts to allow within a job execution.
Specifies the maximum time between retry attempts.

Specifies the coefficient used to calculate the next interval between retries. The following formula is used: (Initial Retry Interval) * Math.pow((Interval Backoff Coefficient), (Number of Retries) - 2).
Specifies the execution policy name.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the execution policy name.
Specifies the time interval to use between job task executions following a job task execution failure.
Specifies the timeout to enforce for overall job execution time.
Specifies the total number of job task execution retry attempts to allow within a job execution.
Specifies the maximum time between retry attempts.

Specifies the coefficient used to calculate the next interval between retries. The following formula is used: (Initial Retry Interval) * Math.pow((Interval Backoff Coefficient), (Number of Retries) - 2).

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Create an execution policy
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureSqlDatabaseJobExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicyName "MyCustomExecutionPolicyName" -JobExecutionTimeout ([System.TimeSpan]::FromHours(1)) -InitialRetryInterval ([System.TimeSpan]::FromSeconds(1)) -RetryIntervalBackoffCoefficient 1.0 -MaximumAttempts 100 -MaximumRetryInterval ([System.TimeSpan]::FromSeconds(30)) ExecutionPolicyName : myCustomExecutionPolicyName JobExecutionTimeout : 01:00:00 InitialRetryInterval : 00:00:01 RetryIntervalBackoffCoefficient : 1 MaximumRetryInterval : 00:00:30 MaximumAttempts : 100

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates an execution policy named MyCustomExecutionPolicyName.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Create a schedule with a time trigger
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureSqlJobSchedule -ScheduleName "MyOneMinuteIntervalSchedule" -StartTime (Get-Date).ToUniversalTime() -MinuteInterval 1 ScheduleName Interval StartTime EndTime ------------ -------- --------- ------- MyOneMinuteIntervalSchedule Minutes: 1 7/4/2015 7:00:00 AM -07:00 12/31/9999 3:59:59 PM -08:00

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a schedule to be triggered every one minute.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Create a schedule with a trigger of one hour
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureSqlJobSchedule -ScheduleName "MyOneHourIntervalSchedule" -MinuteInterval 1 ScheduleName Interval StartTime EndTime ------------ -------- --------- ------- MyOneHourIntervalSchedule Hours: 1 7/4/2015 7:00:00 AM -07:00 12/31/9999 3:59:59 PM -08:00

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a schedule to be triggered every one hour.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Create a schedule with a trigger of one day
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureSqlJobSchedule -ScheduleName "MyOneHourIntervalSchedule" -DayInterval 1 ScheduleName Interval StartTime EndTime ------------ -------- --------- ------- MyOneDayIntervalSchedule Days: 1 7/4/2015 7:00:00 AM -07:00 12/31/9999 3:59:59 PM -08:00

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a schedule to be triggered every one day.

command:example.maml:title: Example 4: Create a schedule that is triggered at a specific time
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureSqlJobSchedule -ScheduleName "MyOneTimeSchedule" -StartTime (New-Object -TypeName System.DateTime -ArgumentList (2015, 07, 15, 07, 00, 00)).ToUniversalTime() -OneTime ScheduleName Interval StartTime EndTime ------------ -------- --------- ------- MyOneTimeSchedule OneTime 7/15/2015 7:00:00 AM -07:00 12/31/9999 3:59:59 PM -08:00

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a schedule to be triggered once at the provided start time.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a set of databases that can be used as a target for jobs.

PS C:\>New-AzureSqlJobTarget -ServerName "MyServer.database.contoso.net" -DatabaseName "MyDatabase" TargetDescription : {"ServerName":"myServer.database.windows.net","DatabaseName":"myDatabase"} ServerName : myServer.database.windows.net DatabaseName : myDatabase TargetId : caab9f96-e34a-4c51-9df9-feb33f5cdb50
TargetType : Database

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Create a custom collection
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureSqlJobTarget -CustomCollectionName "MyCustomCollection" TargetDescription CustomCollectionName TargetId TargetType ----------------- -------------------- -------- ---------- {"CustomCollectionName":"m... MyCustomCollection b525727e-6ed0-44cc-94da-63... CustomCollection

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Create an Elastic Scale shared map target
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureSqlJobTarget -ShardMapManagerServerName "MyShardMapManagerServer.database.contoso.net" -ShardMapManagerDatabaseName "MyShardMapManagerDatabase" -ShardMapManagerCredentialName "MyShardMapCredentials" -ShardMapName "MyShardMap" TargetDescription : {"ShardMapName":"MyShardMap","ShardMapManagerServerName":"MyShardMapManagerServer.dat abase.windows.net","ShardMapManagerDatabaseName":"MyShardMapManagerDatabase"} ShardMapName : MyShardMap ShardMapManagerServerName : myShardMapManagerServer.database.windows.net ShardMapManagerDatabaseName : myShardMapManagerDatabase ShardMapManagerDatabaseTargetId : 9eb3ee50-e4b2-4feb-b2f7-3ee1cd7f7997 ShardMapManagerCredentialName : MyShardMapCredentials TargetId : 1afd9326-1277-4344-832f-8170d0375ff7 TargetType : ShardMap

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates an Elastic Scale shared map target using the provided shard map server name, database name and name. Job runs targeting the shard map target expand to run against each database shard in the shard map. The database shards within the shard map are determined by the system through connecting to the shard map database using the specified shard map credentials. A database target for the database server and the database must first be created along with the credentials.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a job definition to be used for subsequent job runs.
The New-AzureSqlJob cmdlet creates a job definition to be used for subsequent job runs.
Job execution can be requested through the Start-AzureSqlJobExecution cmdlet or through creation of a trigger in combination with a schedule using the New-AzureSqlJobTrigger cmdlet.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the execution policy to use during job execution. If you do not specify this parameter, the default job execution policy is used.
Specifies the name of the content to run or be applied during the job.
Specifies the name of the credentials to use when connecting to target databases.
Specifies the name to use for the new job.
Specifies the name of the credential to use for the database connection used for insertion of the first result set obtained during job execution.
Specifies the database name to use for insertion of the first result set obtained during job execution.
Specifies the database schema name to use for insertion of the first result set obtained during job execution.
Specifies the database schema name to use for insertion of the first result set obtained during job execution.

Specifies the database table name to use for insertion of the first result set obtained during job execution. If the table does not exist during job execution, the system automatically creates it using a schema matching the result set.
Specifies the target ID to use for execution or application of the content during job execution.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the execution policy to use during job execution. If you do not specify this parameter, the default job execution policy is used.
Specifies the name of the content to run or be applied during the job.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a job and its job run history from the system.
The Remove-AzureSqlJob cmdlet removes a job and its job run history from the system.

Job and job run history deletion takes place asynchronously. Any active jobs will not be automatically canceled by the system. If you want to cancel an active job, use the Stop-AzureSqlJobExecution cmdlet. The job and job execution history will be deleted following the completion of any active job executions of the job.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets a job execution policy.
The Set-AzureSqlJobExecutionPolicy cmdlet sets a job execution policy.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Specifies the time interval to use between job tasks following a job task execution failure.
Specifies the timeout to enforce for overall job time.
Specifies the total number of job task execution retry attempts within a job.
Specifies the maximum time to allow to pass between retry attempts.

Specifies the coefficient used to calculate the next interval between retries. The following formula is used: (Initial Retry Interval) * Math.pow((Interval Backoff Coefficient), (Number of Retries) - 2).
Specifies the execution policy name.

Specifies the coefficient used to calculate the next interval between retries. The following formula is used: (Initial Retry Interval) * Math.pow((Interval Backoff Coefficient), (Number of Retries) - 2).

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the Azure PowerShell session context to use the provided connection to the Elastic Database Jobs control database.
The Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet sets the Azure PowerShell session context to use the provided connection to the Elastic Database jobs control database.
Subsequent Elastic Database Jobs cmdlet invocations will make use of the connection information specified within the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet invocation.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Set the PowerShell session context to use the provided connection to the Elastic Database jobs control database previously installed
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Use-AzureSqlJobConnection -CurrentAzureSubscription

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the Azure PowerShell session context to use a connection to the Elastic Database Jobs database previously installed within the current Azure subscription within the __ElasticDatabaseJobs resource group. Following the cmdlet invocation, credentials will be prompted.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Set the PowerShell session context to use the provided connection to the Elastic Database jobs control database.
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Use-AzureSqlJobConnection -ServerName "MyServer" -DatabaseName "MyDatabase"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the Azure PowerShell session context to use a connection to the Elastic Database jobs database named MyDatabase. You are then prompted for credentials after the cmdlet runs.

maml:description.maml:para: Waits for the provided job execution to complete.
The Wait-AzureSqlJobExecution cmdlet waits for the provided job execution to complete.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.
Indicates that the cmdlet will wait for only one provided job to complete rather than all.
Specifies the time duration before this cmdlet times out.
Specifies JobExecutionInfo object(s) on which to wait. JobExecutionInfo objects can be obtained using the Get-AzureSqlJobExecution cmdlet.

Specifies the connection state object for the job. You can get the connection state object through the New-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the connection state is used from a prior call to the Use-AzureSqlJobConnection cmdlet.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Wait for a specific job execute to complete
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Wait-AzureSqlJobExecution -JobExecutionId 07981e74-5235-48a6-b24e-b5beb16a149a

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command waits for the provided job execution to complete.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Wait for a specific job execution to complete after a time duration
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Wait-AzureSqlJobExecution -JobExecutionId 07981e74-5235-48a6-b24e-b5beb16a149a -TimeoutSeconds 60

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command waits for the provided job execution to complete, timing out after 60 seconds.
